title: Which presidential candidate will win North Carolina?
preds: *This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*

confirmed in 2 polls from Qunnipiac and NYT-Marist that 2 % persists.
early voting said to be bad for dems.
to me NC and FLA are close but HRC wins either Trump has no path
I am betting on the turnout from Research Triangle Trumping White rural vote.
But for forecasting race at national level I assume that DT wins FLA and NC  as  a worst case scenario.
My model HRC loses Ohio, FLA and Nevada. early voting indicates he is losing all 
except NC

Late polls paint a picture of Secretary Clinton surging here.  But I still have a hard time believing that she will outperform President Obama's 2012 outcome, and he still lost NC that year.  So I am hedging--no longer saying NC is a sure thing for Mr. Trump--but I still give the advantage to the Republican nominee, slight though that advantage may be.
Updated to reflect early voting trends (including 20-something Democrats going down, African American votes going down, and registered Democrats going down).
My projections show Trump's odds of winning to be between 51% and 62%, but I would not be terribly surprised if this is wrong due to the poor quality of the data

In my previous forecast I cited the NYT upshot projection in North Carolina: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/370098 They've updated with their latest poll, which tightened the final projection quite a bit to right around where the polling average has suggested the race would be all along with about a 1% win for Clinton.  The new poll didn't change their estimates of Clinton's margin in the early vote very much though, suggesting an uphill battle for Trump to close the gap even to 1%. Overall polling averages have pretty consistently had Clinton with about a 1-2% lead in North Carolina, and I haven't seen any information to contradict them.

Sticking with 538, giving Clinton a slight edge as the recent news related to her emails is positive for her.
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/georgia/
In the swing state of North Carolina, Trump has the slight lead, 47.8% to Clinton's 46%. FiveThirtyEight gives Trump a 50.4% chance of winning the state, but Clinton is certainly not far behind
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

I have difficulty believing that a state that President Obama could not carry in 2012 will flip to Secretary Clinton in 2016. This state is trending purple, no doubt about it.  And it may ultimately go blue, in a few election cycles.  However I do not believe the demographics are there yet to support it.

North Carolina is a Republican-leaning state, backing only two Democrats in the last fifty years. That gives us a baseline of c.70% Trump. Its demographics (high White population, lower Latino population) benefit Trump. The polls are also suggesting a Trump win. The state also swung to The Republicans in the midterms. Everything here says a Trump win.

Someone found a great article before I did - here it is:  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/372048 Here is the link of interest (presented as much to myself as a reminder): http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/north-carolina-early-vote-tracker.html Real data (or as close as we can voodoo out real data.)  I just read this article, it is excellent.  I believe it also shows "boots on the ground", or the Hillary ground game (as opposed to the local Donald duck).  The thing to notice is the percent of NC that has already voted - it's HUGE.  We all have been watching polls, but we finally have some early voting facts (well, projections).  Adjusting numbers based on this article.
Major polls + analysis stabilizing, but Trump still has the edge..
Obama spent some time in NC the last day or two and had some bigger rallies, which I think will help.  Also, Nate Silver has NC as being closer (52/48, in favor of Trump) and I agree with this.
HC has consistently led, even if the margin is small and reducing.

RCP polling average gives Trump the lead by .8 pts http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/nc/north_carolina_trump_vs_clinton_vs_johnson-5951.html 538 is giving Trump a 51.5% prob of winning the state:
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/north-carolina/ African American early voting in that state is down this year which is affecting Clinton. But Clinton GOTV efforts in that state seem to be more significant.

This small market local poll shows Trump making a major gain over last go-round 3 weeks ago, link here
http://www.wral.com/wral-poll-trump-charges-ahead-in-nc/16183780/
DJT appeals to middle class white men which gives him a slight advantage.

Clinton and her surrogates are pressing hard in NC.  If the ground game can overcome efforts to suppress the black vote, I expect a significant win.  While voting among African Americans has been slower than anticipated I think the current activity of Obama in that state will move the needle.

The NYT Upshot has been using an interesting combination of polling, voter files, and early voting data in North Carolina: http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/north-carolina-early-vote-tracker.html While it is still an estimate, I consider it a more informative estimate than a typical poll, and it is suggestive of an easy Clinton win in North Carolina and a miss by the polling average in North Carolina, which could have implications in other states. I'm bumping my forecast of a Clinton win up a bit.

Based on recent polls, I give the edge to Donald Trump.  Hillary and Donald have been campaigning there all day, so internal polling is probably tight.  This is also based on reports of lower African-American turnout likely to support Hillary Clinton.
Too high - time to move down with the polls.  Still counting on the Hillary get out the vote machine.

African American early voting turnout is down so far, which is not good news for Hillary. There were several GOP-led legislature rules imposing restrictions on early voting this year that are said to affect African American early voting but there is also a decline on early voting in Florida for that demographic... As for polls, Quinnipiac's latest released today, has Hillary with a 47% lead, Trump at 44%, Johnson 3%, and 5%  undecided. (Jill Stein is not on the ballot there).  Among early voters in that state, Quinnipiac has Clinton leading by 22 pts.  The poll indicates Hillary's lead is within its margin of error. If it gets any closer, we should take a closer look at GOTV of African Americans.  In a call with Hillary's volunteers this past weekend, POTUS used North Carolina's close win in 2008 and close loss in 2012 as examples of how much effort needs to be put into. Calling center for Clinton on the east coast are right now focusing on calls to voters in NC.  http://www.politico.com/blogs/swing-states-2016-election/2016/11/clinton-trump-polls-florida-north-carolina-pennsylvania-ohio-230645#ixzz4OylrUSK7
In Florida, North Carolina and Ohio, which allow early voting, Clinton has large leads. In Florida, she leads by six percentage points among early voters. (Politico.com)

Expecting North Carolina's ~40% ACA premium increase (http://www.thefiscaltimes.com/2016/11/01/Here-s-How-Much-Obamacare-Premiums-Are-Rising-All-50-States) to shock many voters back to Trump, in addition to general race tightening (cycle) through mid-end of week.

leaders in the polls have swapped spots almost 5 times since june - july (roughly). will to guesstimate that the pollings not quite reaching everybody. Polls with higher volume of input also seemed to be more split down the middle than those with smaller but more "reputable" sample sizes.

Back in the 60s North Carolina was often a couple of years ahead of the rest of us, but then they got scared and hid under the bed for a few decades.  Looks like they're back.  This will probably be the year when North Carolina rejoins us in the present calendar century, as Virginia did a few years ago and Tennessee will do over the next four or five. Based off of current Nate Silver prediction, which I think (somewhat intentionally) undervalues the effect of campaign organization in November at this point.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Clinton is currently up 2.0% based on Polling Averages. Fivethirtyeight gives Clinton an 70.6% chance of winning based on Polls only, 52.8% on polls plus. Has voted Republican in every major presidential election since 1980 except for Obama in 2008. Due to the exit of manufacturing jobs in the state and the influx of jobs in the banking and technology fields, demographics have shifted towards voters with college degrees, which favors Clinton. Trump seems to be backing off some of his more outlandish and incendiary statements and policies under new leadership, which may help his chances. However, the damage is most likely done. I put the chances as significantly higher than fivethirtyeights polls plus, which is based on economic and historical data. I think this slightly underestimates Clinton's chances based on the unprecedented campaign and likability polling of Donald Trump and a possible shift in voting demographics since 2012. I put Clinton's chances slightly below current polling because of Trump's recent campaign shakeup and recent backtracking on statements that demonstrate a possible shift in tone of his campaign.
See no evidence of a coordinated campaign from Trump even weeks after the convention. I am ready to switch my forecast strongly to Hillary.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

If the present trend continues with Trump (lack of GOTV, failing or missing campaign infrastructure, and reports even Manafort is mailing it in as no one can control Trump), even a state like NC could go to Hillary in November. The state's governor is fiercely fighting voting laws in court. Will have to see what happens with that. But, as of August, as crazy as it may sound, Hillary might win just like Obama did in '08). Trump made some concessions this week with his endorsement of Paul Ryan and John McCain (which he was refusing to do) and his fundraising is picking up with small donations.  This is one of the most interesting states to watch and perhaps one of the most telling.

Since 1968 only once has NC gone democratic (2008) and by less than a point. Not sure that it will change this time. I would like to know if the voter ID law did suppress some democratic votes in 2012 and if its repeal will have an impact. If it does I will adjust my forecast.

Could go either way but I think it will come down to how many angry NC men vote for Trump vs how many other republicans, especially women, stay home (very few NC republicans will vote for Clinton.. them just staying home or voting for Libertarian candidate is her best hope). On top of that, Clinton also has little of the fresh start qualities necessary to motivate African Americans and other NC democrats for a high turnout as Obama did.
Trump's politics is more populist than Clinton and therefore would be more likely to win North Carolina in November.

OK, we are now post conventions.  Trump has been trump, pulls have changed.  They should settle in a few weeks, but for now, staying with 50% Hillary.  538 is around 45%, Upshot is 50%.  Waiting for more data.
Trump cannot help but shoot himself

This is really conflicted, however I will predict that Clinton will take NC by a small margin. NC's population is 8.8% Hispanic, and I will assign maybe 70% of them will vote for Clinton of all the number of people that will vote in this election (disregarding the difference in number of voters based on socioeconomic and race), which is roughly 6.16% of the population. That being said, of the remaining 91%, roughly 20% are categorized as black. With Trump raising racial tensions I assume that 60% of the black population will vote for Clinton. So far the scoreboard is: Clinton: 18% vs Trump: 11%. The white category takes up around 67%, with the remaining being other. At this point I would like to examine this by age. The older people tend to go with Trump, especially since Trump owns a good portion of real estate in NC (golf courses, residential, etc). Plus age correlates with conservatives. VERY roughly I classified "old" as over 50. This broke down into 41% of people of voting age were classified as young and 59% as old. This of course skewed because a lot of people are transplants and come to NC to retire, and this isn't a typical election. Here I made a educated guess that the young were skewed 55/45 in favor of Democrat and the old were skewed 60/40 in favor of Republicans. I based this on the fact that historically NC is a red state. This updates the scoreboard to: Clinton: 48.91 Trump: 47.06. The remaining 4% are from other races and will probably skew towards Clinton's favor. Again this is a rough estimate.

North Carolina has been trending more Democratic in recent elections, similar to Georgia and Virginia.  I would expect it to still be very close based just on trends, but polls have been stronger for Clinton than in other swing states such as Ohio.

The Appeals Court just struck down North Carolina's voter ID law.  This works in favor of increased Democratic turnout.  But North Carolina has been violating voters' rights since Jesse Helms' earliest days as Senator.  The state has been notorious for preventing black people from voting. The state has seen an influx of liberal voters in some urban areas.  Currently, 30% of the population - not necessarily voters - is hispanic, black, or other non-white.  The state went to Obama in 2008, then to Romney in 2012.  The margins were very close.  This is a close call state.  It's foolish, perhaps, to forecast an outcome before the debates. Nevertheless, I'll call it for the Republicans by about 6 percentage points.
Clinton may abandon NC to focus on PA and FL
A large number of retired ex-military reside in N.C., and they will carry the state for The Donald.

It is the state with growing minorities. The gerrymandering used there does not work in state-wide elections. The only Republican tactic there  was based on a blatant vote suppression that was defeated by the courts. If vote turnout is great, Hillary should win this state.

North Carolina has definitely turned a purple trending blue. The large minority population and the many college towns with its many northern transplants will carry the state for Hillary.
The antebellum culture and heritage is declining in population and will not have enough votes for the Donald.

Felt dirty after all these pro Hillary calls, nice to calling a Trump win for once. Don't buy Hillary can win by a landslide, even if she wins by a safe margin.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner
Starting with 538's Hillary 40%, Donald 60%, and modifying as per my post here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/292589

Court just threw out several elements of the state's Stop-Dems-From-Voting law.  Might help.  And as in several other states, the Ds could benefit from demographic shifts as long as their constituents can get registered and hie themselves to the polls.
Trump might have dropped out by election night.
Clinton will not get the African-American turnout that Obama did. Trump energizes a voting bloc that Romney couldn't. He should have significant advantage here.

538 uses early-July Marist poll and national-trend data to weight towards Trump (on polls-only). Circuit Court opinion today will open up at least 100-200K more votes with injunction against racially-disparate voter ID law. I'm guessing NC will follow VA, if less decisively. Waiting for more polls -- hope someone reliable like Marist is out in the field next week.

Hillary won the North Carolina primary with 54.6% (616,383 votes), Bernie got  40.8% (460,316)
Trump 
Trump won the GOP primary with 40.2% (458,151) followed by Ted Cruz who got 36.8% (418,740), Kasich 12.7%
(144,299), and Marco Rubio with 7.7% (87,858) In the 2012 Presidential election, Mitt Romeny won 50.39% of the vote and Barack Obama received 48.35%.
In 2008, Obama won the state by a small margin of 0.32% over John McCain.    For more info on the state's voting history: http://www.270towin.com/states/North_Carolina There are many reports of African American voter suppression (suspension of early voting in some areas, or reducing the period from 17 days to 7, or trying to eliminate early Sunday voters which is an African American tradition of taking church goers to early voting on Sundays.  Also allegations of suppression regarding voting id for African Americans.  A NC Court (don't have link but can get it if anyone is interested) said that there was no evidence of racial discrimination but that there was evidence of suppression of voters who were not Republican in the state.)  Given that high turn out by African American voters gave Barack Obama the victory in the state in 2008 is significant.   The state's governor, Pat McCrory has joined Trump and is showing up with him at rallies. It's useful to remember that North Carolina is the state banning transgenders from using bathrooms assigned to their gender identity which created much controversy along with loss of millions in business and investments. As for polls, some show Trump leading by a small percentage while others show them going neck and neck (much to my surprise, I expected Trump to be leading by a lot more points) I will have to take a look at the economic numbers in the state, the campaign operations mounted there, and any leads on GOTV, new voter registration.  For now, I will give Trump the advantage given the state's voting history.  But still need to research demographics and economic data further.

Trump voters will be more motivated to come out and vote.  North Carolina conservative voters have been hammered hard by Federal judges and government.  Future of Supreme Court appointments will pull in the voters who favor Trump.
